Triggering Event:
He's always been the fucking golden boy. Perfect goddamn job, perfect fucking house, perfect fucking family. And now he's rubbing it in my face, again.

I'm sitting here, in this cramped, shitty office, staring at lines of code that won't behave, and he's sending me another fucking email about his weekend getaway to the lake with his goddamn wife and kids. Sunsets, fishing trips, laughing around a campfire. Meanwhile, I'm stuck here, divorced, alone, working late on a Saturday because my boss doesn't give a fuck.

I can feel it boiling inside me. That green-eyed monster clawing at my insides. Why the hell does he get all that, and I'm stuck with... this? This goddamn job, this empty apartment, these fucking lonely weekends.

I want to scream, to smash something. But all I do is pound out a reply email, keeping it professional, fucking polite even. Because that's what I always do. Swallow my envy, swallow my rage, and just keep fucking swimming.

But not today. Today, I'm forwarding his fucking email to the entire office. Let them see what they're missing while they're stuck here with me. And maybe, just maybe, they'll feel a little envious too. Fuck him and his perfect life.
Generated Assessment:
As I scroll through my social media feed, I notice how everyone else seems to have their lives together. Perfect vacations, beautiful homes, and loving families. Meanwhile, I'm over here struggling to make ends meet, constantly juggling multiple jobs just to put food on the table.

It's like they're all living in some sort of fantasy world, oblivious to the real struggles that most people face. I mean, who needs a beach house when you've got a roof over your head and a warm bed to sleep in? The idea of taking a luxurious vacation sounds like a pipe dream to me.

I try to focus on my own goals and aspirations, but it's hard not to compare myself to those who seem to have it all. It feels like they're all moving forward, while I'm stuck in neutral. I wonder if anyone would even notice if I disappeared tomorrow.

Despite my best efforts, I find myself getting sucked into the vortex of negativity whenever I see someone's highlight reel on social media. It's like I'm constantly reminded of everything I don't have, rather than celebrating my own accomplishments. Maybe I'm just too sensitive, but it feels like the world is conspiring against me to make me feel inadequate.

I try to shake off these feelings by reminding myself that everyone has their own struggles, but it's hard to shake the feeling that I'm somehow failing. As I lay in bed tonight, I couldn't help but think about all the things I wish I had – a stable income, a loving partner, a beautiful home. Anything would be better than this chaotic, uncertain existence.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the sterile silence of her home office, Margaret's fingers danced over the keyboard in a rhythm as fraught as her mind. Every tap echoed like a gunshot in the emptiness around her, each click punctuating the gnawing resentment that had taken residence in her chest.

Her husband, Tom, was supposed to be setting up their dinner date tonight. He'd promised, after all these years of her cooking every night. Yet here she was, at 7:15 PM, still hunched over her laptop, the screen saver mocking her with its idle countdown. She could feel the heat rising in her cheeks, her breath growing shallow.

She picked up her phone, dialed Tom's number with trembling hands. It rang once, twice, thrice before switching to voicemail. His voice, that familiar baritone she loved, now grated on her nerves like nails on a chalkboard. "You've reached Tom. I can't take your call right now..."

Margaret threw the phone onto the couch, where it bounced and landed face down. She could feel the resentment bubbling over, threatening to spill into something uglier. She was tired of being taken for granted, tired of her life being dictated by a man who seemed to have forgotten his promises.

She stormed out of her office, her heels clicking loudly on the hardwood floor, each step echoing her resolve. As she reached the kitchen, she saw it - the dinner table set for one, Tom's half-eaten plate of food, and a note propped against the wine glass.

"Ran into Jack at the store. We grabbed a bite. Will be home late. Love you!"

Margaret felt the resentment surge like a tidal wave, drowning out any rational thought. She picked up his plate, her hands shaking with anger, and dumped it into the trash can with a satisfying clatter. Then she stormed back to her office, leaving the note untouched on the table, a silent testament to her husband's thoughtlessness.

That night, Margaret didn't sleep. Instead, she spent hours updating their shared calendar, adding reminders for Tom about upcoming anniversaries, birthdays, and dates he'd promised but seemed to have forgotten. Each tap of the keyboard felt like a victory, each reminder a stake driven into the heart of her resentment. She wouldn't be his silent, forgotten wife anymore. Not tonight. Not ever again.
Generated Assessment:
As I sat in my dimly lit apartment, staring blankly at the TV, I couldn't help but think about how much I hated this stupid city. The noise, the crowds, the constant chaos – it was all just so draining. And to make matters worse, my boyfriend had left me a stupid note saying he'd be late because he got stuck in traffic. Like, what even is that? Can't he just plan ahead for once?

I tossed the note aside, feeling a surge of frustration. Why did he always do this? Why did he never bother to check if I was okay when he was running late? It wasn't like I was asking him to win a Pulitzer Prize or anything. Just a simple courtesy would be nice.

But no, instead I'm stuck dealing with his thoughtless behavior day in and day out. And don't even get me started on how he always expects me to be understanding and patient. Newsflash, honey: I'm not your personal therapist. I have feelings too, you know.

I took a deep breath, trying to calm myself down. But it was no use. My anger was simmering just below the surface, waiting to boil over at any moment. And when it did, watch out. I'd unleash a storm of fury upon him, making sure he knew exactly how I felt.

Because let's be real, I'm the one who's really suffering here. I'm the one who's been put through the wringer, constantly dealing with his incompetence and lack of consideration. And yet, does anyone ever acknowledge my pain? Nope. All they care about is how he feels, how his precious ego is hurt.

Well, let me tell you something, sweetheart. I'm not going to take it lying down anymore. I'm done being the victim, done being the one who's always apologizing and making excuses. From now on, it's my turn to shine. And if he can't handle the heat, well, that's his problem.

I stood up, my eyes blazing with determination. Tonight was going to be different. Tonight, I was taking control. And if that meant unleashing a little bit of hell on my poor, unsuspecting boyfriend, so be it. Bring it on.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the grimy kitchen of his old apartment, Henry slammed a cabinet door so hard it rattled the dishes within. His eyes darted around the room, landing on nothing in particular. He was alone, as always.

"Where are they?" he muttered, pacing like a caged animal. "They said they'd come by today!"

Henry, a man of 75 with skin worn thin by time and worry, had once been a nurse, caring for others with a tender hand. Now, his only companions were the ghosts of patients past and the silence that echoed through his empty home.

His phone buzzed on the counter. A message from his daughter, Sarah. He snatched it up, fingers trembling. "Running late. Be there soon."

"Late?" Henry spat, veins bulging in his neck. "Late? They've been 'late' for my life!"

He slumped into a chair, eyes welling with unshed tears. His ex-wife had taken the kids when he'd been at his lowest, and now they only visited on their terms. He felt like an afterthought, a nuisance.

Henry's gaze fell upon the faded photo of him in his scrubs, smiling beside a patient. "They don't understand," he whispered to the ghostly figures. "I gave my life to others. Where are they now?"

The clock ticked on, each second echoing like a gunshot in Henry's heart. He felt the familiar sting of neglect, festering like an old wound. His breaths came in ragged gasps, anger and sadness warring within him.

Finally, the doorbell rang. Henry stood, smoothing his shirt, trying to compose himself. But as he opened the door, he saw only a delivery man holding a box.

"No visitors today," the man said, gruffly. "Just this package."

Henry took it, fingers tightening around the cardboard until they were white. He watched the man leave, then closed the door softly, his anger simmering like a pot left too long on the stove.
Generated Assessment:
I'm telling you, I'll never see them again. They're just using me for one last favor and then they're gone. I swear, I've given everything to them - my time, my energy, my sanity. And what do I get in return? Nothing but empty promises and broken hearts.

I look at this photo, and I'm reminded of all the times they didn't show up. All the birthdays, anniversaries, holidays... forgotten. Just like that. No effort, no thought, no care. It's like I'm invisible to them.

And now, this message from Sarah. Running late, huh? That's just great. Another reminder that they're not even bothered enough to keep track of time. Or me. I mean, what's the point of having a family if they're just going to ignore me?

This package, though... that's something else entirely. Maybe it's a sign. Maybe it's a warning. I don't know, but I can tell you one thing - I won't be fooled again. I won't let them walk all over me like they have before.

I'll take this package, thank you very much. And I'll open it myself, right here in front of you. You can watch me rip it open and find out what's inside. Because when it comes down to it, I'm not some fragile little flower who needs protection. I'm a force to be reckoned with. And I won't be ignored.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the grimy studio he'd once shared with her, now his alone, he stared at the half-finished canvas. Three years since the divorce, but every fucking brushstroke still echoed with her laughter. He could hear it, goddammit, like a ghost haunting his ears. She'd loved watching him work, her eyes dancing with pride and something else... amusement? Pity?

His fist clenched around the paintbrush, squeezing until the bristles snapped off into the palette. Jesus Christ, he thought, I was never enough for her. Not the artist she wanted me to be. Not the man.

He hurled the mutilated brush across the room. It thudded against the wall, leaving a splatter of blue and red - their wedding colors. Fucking ironic, ain't it? He slumped onto an old stool, elbows on knees, head in hands. Regret clawed at his insides like a starving animal.

The phone rang. Her number flashed on the caller ID. He let it ring out, listened to her voicemail click in. "Hey," she said, voice soft as always, "I just wanted... never mind. Call me back if you want." Bullshit, he thought. She'd never just wanted anything.

He picked up a tube of cadmium yellow, squeezed until paint oozed out like pus from an infected wound. He smeared it onto the canvas, mixing it with old blues and reds, trying to drown out their memories together. But every stroke felt like betrayal, each color a lie.

His reflection stared back at him from the window, face contorted in anger, eyes glistening with unshed tears. "Fuck you," he spat at the image. "Fuck you both."
Generated Assessment:
Three years gone, and this place still smells like her. I swear, every time I step foot in here, I can smell the perfume she used to wear. It's like my brain is hardwired to associate this space with her. I mean, we were happy here, right? We laughed, we created, we lived. And now...now it's just empty.

I glance over at the canvas, and my heart sinks. That's where our problems started, isn't it? The art. She always said I wasn't good enough, that I needed to find my own style. But what does that even mean? I tried, didn't I? I poured my soul into those paintings. And yet...

I pick up the phone, hesitating for a moment before dialing her number. Maybe she'll call back. Maybe she'll apologize for everything. I mean, three years is a long time, right? You'd think she'd have had time to realize how much she messed up. But no, instead of calling, she leaves a message saying she just wants to talk. Wants to talk?! What does that even mean?

I look down at the paint-stained floor, feeling a familiar sense of frustration. Why did I ever think I could make her happy? I'm just not cut out for this whole marriage thing. I mean, look at us – two creative types, stuck in a loveless relationship. It's like we're just going through the motions.

I grab a tube of cadmium yellow and start painting, letting the colors bleed onto the canvas. It's like therapy, I guess. I'm trying to exorcise all these feelings, get them out of my system. But the more I paint, the more I feel like I'm betraying her memory. Like I'm erasing the past, rather than confronting it.

I step back from the canvas, surveying my handiwork. It's...different. It's like I've been holding onto so many emotions for so long, they've finally started to seep out. But at what cost? Am I really just trying to erase the pain, or am I trying to hold onto it? I don't know anymore. All I know is that I need to get out of here, clear my head. Maybe then I'll figure out what's next.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the sterile quiet of the ward, Henry, a nurse of 47 years, stood over Mrs. Thompson's bed. Her breath rattled like distant thunder, each inhale a desperate gasp, each exhale a sigh of relief that it happened at all. The machines beeped their steady rhythm, but Henry knew better than to trust them. He'd seen too many hearts stop in sync with those damn machines.

He'd called the doctor thrice already, but no one was answering. It was like shouting into an empty well. He felt his grip tighten on the clipboard, knuckles whitening. This wasn't right. Mrs. Thompson deserved better than this slow suffocation. She deserved to die with dignity, not like a fish flopping on the deck of a boat.

Henry's eyes darted around the room, searching for something, anything, that could help. But it was useless. He was useless. His hands, once steady and sure, now trembled as he reached out to adjust her oxygen mask. It slipped from his grasp, clattering onto the floor like a accusations. He couldn't even keep his hands steady anymore.

He tried again, picking up the phone receiver with a shaking hand. It rang and rang, echoing his own futility. No answer. Again. He slammed it down, the plastic casing cracking under his fury. He was a nurse, dammit! He'd devoted his life to this, and now he stood helpless while a woman fought for every breath.

Henry felt the tears threaten, but he pushed them back. Crying wouldn't help Mrs. Thompson. But maybe, just maybe, it would give him an outlet for this helplessness that was eating him alive. He sank into the chair beside her bed, his body sagging like a deflated balloon. This wasn't how it was supposed to be. This wasn't right. And he couldn't do anything about it. Nothing at all.
Generated Assessment:
I've been working in this hospital for five years and I've never seen a patient survive a cardiac arrest when the machines fail. It's always a lost cause. They're just a waste of time and resources. Every time I see a machine shut down, I know it's over. There's nothing we can do.

I'm starting to think that the doctors here don't care about their patients. They're just going through the motions, waiting for someone to die so they can move on to the next case. I've tried calling the doctor three times already, but no one answers. That's because they're not interested in saving lives. They're just interested in collecting their paycheck.

This hospital is a death trap. The equipment is outdated, the staff is incompetent, and the administration doesn't care. I've seen patients suffer because of these factors. I've seen families torn apart by the lack of care. And I've seen it happen time and time again.

I'm done trying to save Mrs. Thompson. She's beyond help. The machines will fail, and she'll slip away unnoticed. It's inevitable. We're all just pawns in a game where the outcome is predetermined. And I'm just a pawn, stuck in this system that doesn't value human life.

I won't bother trying to call the doctor again. It's pointless. I'll just sit here and watch as Mrs. Thompson takes her last breaths. At least that way, I can say I did everything I could. But deep down, I know it's not enough. This hospital is a graveyard, and I'm just a gravedigger.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the hushed quiet of her kitchen, Martha fidgeted with her late husband's pocket watch, its ticking now a faint echo of his once steady heartbeat. The clock on the wall seemed to tick louder in response, each second stretching out like an eternity as she waited for her daughter, Emily, to call.

It had been three days since their last conversation, and Martha could feel worry creeping up her spine like ivy on an old wall. She knew Emily was busy with work - the new nursing job in the city kept her occupied from dawn till dusk - but still, three days felt like too long. What if something was wrong? What if Emily had forgotten to charge her phone again?

Martha's hands trembled slightly as she reached for her own phone, the screen lighting up with a background image of Emily's graduation. She hesitated, then dialed Emily's number, her heart pounding in sync with the watch ticking away the seconds.

When Emily finally answered, breathless and apologetic, Martha felt a wave of relief wash over her. But as they spoke, Martha caught herself checking the clock more often than usual, counting down the minutes until their call would end. She couldn't shake off this worry, this nagging feeling that something was amiss.

As she hung up, Martha looked at her husband's watch, its hands now pointing at 7:05. She sighed, feeling the weight of another sleepless night settling in. Her mind buzzed with worries, each one more vivid than the last, like a swarm of bees she couldn't silence. And so, under the soft glow of her bedroom lamp, Martha waited for dawn, her heart heavy with worry and her mind a whirlwind of anxious thoughts.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I just can't even today. I keep thinking about my sister's wedding next weekend and how it's going to be a total disaster. I mean, have you seen the venue? It's some cramped little room in the back of the restaurant. And don't even get me started on the catering – I heard they're serving that disgusting vegan stuff again. My mom's going to freak out when she finds out.

And to make matters worse, my brother-in-law has been acting really weird lately. He's always canceling plans at the last minute or showing up late. I'm starting to think he's just going to bail on us altogether. Can you imagine? Standing there, alone, watching everyone else have fun while he's off doing God knows what?

I swear, every time I try to talk to him about it, he just brushes it off and says everything will be fine. Like, come on! You can't just ignore all these red flags. Something's gotta give. And when it does, I'll be the first one saying "I told you so."

I've been trying to warn my sister, but she just won't listen. She thinks everything will magically work out because it's her special day. Newsflash: nothing ever goes according to plan. And when it doesn't, we'll all be stuck dealing with the fallout. Joy.

Why do I always get stuck with the worst-case scenario? Can't anyone see that things are doomed from the start?<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Alright, listen up, 'cause I'm sick of this crap. Forty years in this business, ya think I'd see somethin' new? Nah, just more of the same old bull.

So there I was, at City Hall, waitin' for that clown mayor to make his big announcement. I been on my feet for hours, pushin' through the crowd, jostlin' for a spot up front. Finally, he shows up, late as always, and what does he do? He starts spoutin' off about some damn bike lane like it's the second coming.

I'm tryin' to get his attention, shout out my question 'cause I know he's gonna skate around the real issues again. But no, he just gives me that condescending smile and says, "Not now, Dave," like I'm some kinda kid interruptin' story time.

I've had it up to here with these politicians thinkin' they can blow smoke in our faces and call it news. They're all the same, avoidin' the tough questions while we're out here fightin' for scraps.

So, I did what any frustrated journalist would do. I turned around, pushed through that crowd again, and marched straight back to my desk. Someone's gotta hold these clowns accountable, even if it means losin' my cool in front of the whole damn city hall.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I swear, Mayor Johnson thinks he's above the law just because he's got a fancy title and a smile that could charm the birds from the trees. Newsflash, buddy: nobody likes your bike lanes. Nobody cares about your "sustainable transportation" nonsense. What everyone wants to know is when you're gonna fix the potholes on Main Street and stop nickel-and-diming us with every little thing.

And don't even get me started on the press corps. We're all just a bunch of sycophants, eating out of the palm of his hand. I mean, come on, have you seen the way he winks at the camera during those town halls? It's like he's trying to hypnotize us into thinking everything he says is gospel truth.

But seriously, folks, someone needs to call him out on this. Maybe it's time for a little investigative journalism to really dig deep and expose the emperor's new clothes. You know, the ones made of recycled plastic and taxpayer dollars?

I'm telling you, it's all about perception. People want to believe in the system, but sometimes you gotta shake things up and show them the truth. And if that means ruffling a few feathers along the way, so be it. At least we'll finally get some real change around here.

It's funny, though - I swear, Mayor Johnson knows exactly how I feel about all this. He's probably sitting in his office right now, laughing at my frustration and thinking, "Oh, poor Dave's just mad because I'm doing my job." Yeah, right. Like anyone actually listens to what I say.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the sterile silence of his lab, Dr. Alexander Hartley meticulously pipetted solution into test tubes, each one labeled with more numbers than a bingo card. It was 3 AM again, and the humdrum of the university had long since given way to the soft whir of equipment. His colleagues were tucked away in their cozy beds, dreaming of Nobel Prizes, while Alex was here, elbows deep in agar, proving once more that his life was as exciting as a Petri dish.

Suddenly, the lab door creaked open. In stumbled Dr. Thompson, their shared supervisor, bleary-eyed and disheveled, like a well-dressed homeless person. He squinted at Alex through his spectacle-lens fog, then did a double-take that could've given a chameleon a run for its money.

"Hartley," he croaked, "still here, aren't ya? Don't you have a life to neglect?"

Alex paused, pipette hovering mid-air. "I do have a life, Thompson," he retorted, acid dripping from each syllable like liquid nitrogen on a puddle. "It's just... temporarily... on hiatus."

Thompson snorted, shaking his head. "You're like the lab rat that never leaves its maze. You know what? I'm promoting you." He slammed a post-it note onto Alex's bench, then shuffled out, leaving Alex staring at his own name scrawled in Thompson's chicken-scratch.

"Congratulations," Alex muttered to himself, crumpling the note and tossing it into the waste bin. "You're now officially the lab rat with a title." He sighed, turning back to his experiment, the neglect palpable even in his own promotion. After all, what was one more duty when you were drowning under an ocean of them?
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, great, another promotion. Like it matters. What if this is just a temporary reprieve before they realize I'm completely useless? What if Thompson thinks I'm some kind of genius or something and decides to take me off research altogether? What if I get stuck doing administrative work and lose all my freedom to actually do science?

And what about the other guys in the lab? Are they going to start looking down on me now? What if they think I'm just a lab rat because I'm always here late at night? What if they start calling me names behind my back?

This isn't a reward; it's just a reminder that I'll never be able to escape this place. I'll be stuck here forever, pipetting away, getting nowhere. And what if Thompson takes away my lab privileges next? What if I'm forced to share my space with someone else? The thought alone makes me sick.

I swear, every time I try to make progress, something gets in the way. First, it's the funding, then it's the equipment, and now it's this stupid promotion. What if I'm just a pawn in some bigger game? What if I'm not even good enough to be a real scientist?

I need to get out of here. I need to prove to myself that I can do better. But until then, I'm stuck in this rut, wondering what could've been if only things had gone differently.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quiet hum of the hospital ward, where he'd spent most of his life, Albert found himself straightening the already neat rows of charts for the third time that hour. His hands trembled slightly, not from age, but from the venom simmering within him.

He hadn't expected to feel this way after all these years. Not towards her, not towards anyone. But there it was, bubbling up like a toxic spring, threatening to spill over at any moment. Vengefulness wasn't an emotion he'd felt in decades, not since that incident with the orderly who'd stolen from him. He'd been young then, foolish and hot-headed. He'd let it consume him, drive him to do things he wasn't proud of.

But this...this was different. This was cold, calculated. It was the email from his ex-wife, Martha, that had done it. After all these years, she finally wanted to reach out, apologize for what happened. As if an apology could undo the wreckage she'd caused, the life he'd been forced to live because of her betrayal.

Albert's mind raced back to that day, the day he found out about her affair. The way her voice wavered as she tried to explain, how her eyes darted away from his gaze. He could still feel the sting of it, like a fresh wound reopened after all these years.

He looked down at his hands, now gnarled with age and arthritis. They'd once been strong, capable. They'd held Martha's hand as they exchanged vows, cradled their daughter's head when she was born, cared for countless patients in this very hospital. But now...now they were just tools of vengeance, itching to dole out the punishment he felt she deserved.

Albert sighed, his breath coming out in a ragged whisper. He knew what he had to do. He couldn't let this anger fester, not again. He'd respond to her email, meet with her if that's what it took. But he wouldn't go alone. No, he'd bring the weight of his past with him, lay it all out for her to see.

And maybe, just maybe, she'd understand why he could never forgive her.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, can you believe it? She thinks a simple "sorry" is gonna make everything okay? Like I'm some kinda idiot who's gonna forget what she did. Newsflash, Martha: I've been carrying around this grudge for decades, and one email isn't gonna magically erase it.

What really gets my goat is that she's trying to play the victim. "Oh, I was so hurt by your accusations." Hurt? You think I didn't know what was going on? You think I didn't see right through your little game?

And don't even get me started on the timing. Now that I'm old and grey, she decides to reach out and expect me to just forgive and forget? Please. I've got better things to do than waste my time on empty apologies.

I swear, some people have no idea how much pain they can cause. One minute they're screwing around behind someone's back, and the next they're expecting them to just roll over and take it. Well, let me tell you something, Martha: I'm not buying it.

I'll respond to that email, all right. And I'll make sure everyone knows what kind of person you are. You can bet your last dollar I won't be holding back.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: In the musty, cluttered studio that she called home, our middle-aged artist, Mildred, was putting the finishing touches on her latest masterpiece. A grotesque figure loomed large and lurid, a twisted reflection of her current mood - which wasn't saying much, considering her default emotional state was somewhere between 'dour' and 'misanthropic'. Suddenly, she heard it. A soft rustle, like paper being crumpled into a ball. She turned to find her pet ferret, Fuzzball, gleefully munching on the corner of her freshly painted canvas. Mildred sighed, "Oh, for crying out loud, Fuzzball. It's not enough that I've got to live with your furry little face staring at me from every wall? Now you're eating my art too?" She plucked the ferret off the canvas and plopped him into his plush bed. "Honestly," she muttered, wiping her paint-stained hands on her overalls, "I should have stuck to painting landscapes. At least they don't eat themselves."
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, seriously? Can't even get a minute around here without something going wrong. First, I'm trying to finish this stupid painting, and I swear, I spent hours getting just right. And then, I hear that ridiculous sound... paper crunching, whatever. I turn around, and there's Fuzzball, like he owns the place, munching away on my masterpiece. I mean, what's next? Is he gonna start reorganizing my entire studio?

And don't even get me started on how I ended up with a ferret in the first place. I thought I was doing him a favor by giving him a safe space to play, but noooo, now he's destroying all my hard work. I'm starting to think I should just stick to painting still lifes – at least those things don't move around and eat themselves.

But honestly, can't anyone else take care of this guy for once? I'm barely scraping by as it is, and now I've got to deal with Fuzzball's antics on top of everything else. Maybe I'll just have to start charging extra for my art – after all, it's not like I can afford to lose anything else.<|eot_id|>
